newsitem.title: TAIWAN: U.S. Treasury official talks of close Taiwan ties.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Treasury official talks of close Taiwan ties.

text.p: U.S. Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers on Sunday said Washington's economic ties with Taipei were becoming increasingly close.
Summers, the highest ranking U.S. official to visit the island since 1994, arrived in Taiwan on Saturday for Monday's one-day trade talks with Taiwanese officials.
Summers and his delegation were scheduled to meet vice economics minister Hsu Ke-sheng and other economic and foreign affairs officials in the one-day talks.

"I very much am looking forward to our economic dialogue. Our economic relations are increasingly close, and I think we will have a lot to discuss and to work together," Summers said on state television.
He did not specify which issues the two sides plan to discuss.
Summers is the first ministerial-level U.S. official to visit Taiwan since Transportation Secretary Federico Pena came to the island in December 1994.
Washington switched diplomatic recognition to China's communist government from Taipei in 1979, keeping only unofficial ties with Taiwan.
Beijing considers Taiwan a rebel-held island in China and strongly opposes official contacts with Taipei.
The delegation headed by Summers includes officials from the U.S. Treasury, State, Trade and Commerce departments and the Federal Reserve. They are scheduled to leave on Tuesday.

Taiwan and China have been separated by a civil war in 1949 and only 30 countries recognise Taiwan's Republic of China government instead of Beijing's communist government. China vows to attack Taiwan if it tries to declare independence.
A visit by Taiwan's President Lee Teng-hui to the United States in 1995 sparked outrage in Beijing.
